title: Aggregator Theory Endgame
context: Digital aggregators (Google, Amazon, Uber, Airbnb) win by owning demand and commoditizing supply. The theory says aggregators create value by reducing transaction costs and improving matching. Initially this is true — consumers get better prices and selection, suppliers get access to customers. But as aggregators achieve dominance, the dynamic inverts. Suppliers become dependent and lose pricing power. Consumers face reduced choice as the aggregator optimizes for its own margins. The platform that started by serving both sides begins extracting from both sides, and switching costs make escape nearly impossible.
hypothesis: Aggregators win by owning demand and create lasting value for all participants.

effects.label: Suppliers become dependent on aggregator for demand

children.label: Supplier margins compressed as platform takes larger cut
Quality of supply degrades as margins shrink
Suppliers cut corners to maintain profitability

effects.label: Consumer choice narrows despite appearance of abundance

children.label: Private label products compete with suppliers using their own data

effects.label: Innovation stalls as aggregator optimizes extraction
effects.impact: R&D shifts from product to monetization

children.label: New entrants cannot compete without aggregator access
Entire industries restructure around aggregator constraints

dontIf: You're building a business entirely dependent on a single aggregator for demand
You assume the aggregator's current take rate will remain stable
ifYouMust: Build direct customer relationships in parallel from day one
Diversify across multiple platforms to reduce single-platform dependency
Track take rate trends and model profitability at 2x current rates

alternatives.name: Direct-to-consumer channels
alternatives.note: Own the customer relationship, even if growth is slower

alternatives.name: Protocol-based marketplaces
alternatives.note: Decentralized alternatives with capped take rates

sources.title: Ben Thompson: Aggregation Theory
sources.note: Original framework for understanding digital aggregator dynamics

sources.title: Lina Khan: Amazon's Antitrust Paradox
sources.note: Legal analysis of aggregator market power and consumer harm

sources.title: ILSR: Amazon Marketplace Report
sources.note: Documents Amazon's rising take rate from 19% to 34% over a decade

falsifiability: Aggregator take rates stabilize or decrease as platforms mature
Suppliers on dominant platforms maintain or improve margins over 5-year periods
New market entrants successfully compete without aggregator platform access

seo.description: Digital aggregators start by serving suppliers and consumers but end up extracting from both. Take rates double from 15% to 30%+ as platform dependency becomes inescapable.
